contentrichtext.text: {{for|the Colombian band|Ekhymosis}} {{Infobox disease | Name = Ecchymoses | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = {{ICD9|459.89}}, {{ICD9|782.7}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D004438 }} An '''ecchymosis''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|ɛ|k|ɨ|ˈ|m|oʊ|s|ɪ|s}}; [[Ancient Greek]]: ἐκχύμωσις, from ἐκ "out" + χέω "I pour") is the medical term for a subcutaneous [[purpura]] larger than 1 centimeter or a [[hematoma]], commonly, but erroneously, called a '''[[bruise]]'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=UCSF Purpura Module|url=http://www.dermatology.ucsf.edu/education_training/140.01ClinicalDermatology/Module.8.Purpura%20Module%20REVISED2.pdf}}</ref> That is, [[bruise]]s are caused by trauma whereas ecchymoses, a type of [[purpura]], are not caused by trauma.<ref>{{cite web|title=Easy Bruising Symptoms|url=http://www.medicinenet.com/easy_bruising/symptoms.htm}}</ref> A broader definition of ecchymosis<ref>Merriam-Webster Dictionary. http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ecchymosis; accessed 1/2/2012</ref><ref>Gould, George M. "The Practitioner's Medical Dictionary," P. Blakiston's Son & Co., 1916 et seq.; p. 311</ref> (noun) \e-ki-ˈmō-səs\ is as: the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels. The term also applies to the sub-cutaneous discoloration resulting from seepage of blood within the contused tissue. ==Term== {{wiktionary|ecchymosis}} * ec·chy·mo·ses (plural) * ec·chy·mot·ic (adjective) * ec·chy·mosed (adjective) * ec·chy·moma — tumor (swelling) or hematoma caused by extravasation. First used in English in the 1541 translation of [[Galen]]'s ''Terapentyke''. Via New Latin from Greek ekchymōsis, from ekchymousthai to extravasate blood, from ex- + chymos "juice" Cf. enchyma, tissue infused with organic juice; elaboration from chyme, the formative juice of tissues. ==Presentation== After local trauma, [[red blood cells]] are [[phagocytosed]] and degraded by [[macrophages]]. The blue-red color is produced by the enzymatic conversion of [[hemoglobin]] into [[bilirubin]], which is more blue-green. The bilirubin is then converted into [[hemosiderin]], a golden brown color, which accounts for the color changes of the bruise.<ref name="rc">Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of Disease 8th edition, pp. 114</ref> Hematomas can be subdivided by size. By definition, ecchymoses are 1 to 2 cm in size or larger, and are therefore larger than [[petechiae|petechia]] (1–2 mm or less) or [[pigmented purpuric dermatosis]] (0.3 to 1 cm).<ref name="rc"/> Hematomas also have a more diffuse border than other purpura.<ref name="urlCase Based Pediatrics Chapter">{{cite web |url=http://www.hawaii.edu/medicine/pediatrics/pedtext/s16c03.html |title=Case Based Pediatrics Chapter |work= |accessdate=2009-01-08}}</ref> == See also == * [[petechiae|petechia]], which is the smallest type of hematoma (<3mm) * [[purpura]], which is the mid-sized type of hematoma (3mm-1 cm) * [[Solar purpura]] * [[pigmented purpuric dermatosis]] * [[black eye]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Hemodynamics}} {{General injuries}} [[Category:Dermatologic terminology]] [[Category:Medical signs]]
